item.title: By: Eleni Hailu
item.dc:creator: Eleni Hailu
item.description:
BradB:  I had the same issue like you but after multiple call to paypal I managed to fix the problem.  You need to update the certificate not only in the root but also inside the Coldfusion folder - YOU HAVE TO DO IT IN BOTH PLACES.  Below is the information they provide in connection with this:
1. Download the certs from VeriSign at https://www.verisign.com/support/roots.html
2. Open zip and location the Cert file that needs to be updated. In this case the "VeriSign Class 3 - G2". Take note of it&apos;s location on the server. Recommend renaming it to have no spaces and then putting it in the "C:\CFusiomMX7\runtime\jre\lib\security" folder.
3. Open command prompt and type "cd c:\CFusionmx7\runtime\jre\bin" or the location of the "keytool.exe" file and hit enter. Don&apos;t try to run the keytool.exe without the next step. It won&apos;t hurt anything, but it won&apos;t do anything either.
4. Now type the following replacing what it necessary (such as the cert file name from step 2 above and alias name)
keytool -import -trustcacerts - keystore c:/cfusionmx7/runtime/jre/lib/security/cacerts -file c:/cfusionmx7/runtime/jre/lib/security/Class_3_Public_Primary_Certification_Authority_G2.cer -alias VeriSignG2
5. You&apos;ll be prompted for a password and as long as you haven&apos;t ever changed it, it should be "changeit", which is the default.
6. You&apos;ll be prompted to approve the request. Type "yes" without the quotes and hit enter
7. A bunch of text should appear validating the installation. If you get an error, make sure your path and file names are correct in the step above.
8. To verify, go to the jre\lib\security directory in Windows Explorer and make sure the files modified date is today&apos;s date.
Hope this will help.
Thanks,
Eleni

item.title: By: BradB
item.dc:creator: BradB
item.description: Thanks Ryan and ben.  It clearly seems to be related to the cert update, though so far the G2 update (I am also the host) does not seem to resolve the problem.  The folks at Paypal seem to be willing to reluctanty admit an issue, but appear to have no method of resolution.  It may be complicated by the fact that I buy my certs from Comodo and there are G2 root certs from different authorities (Verisign, Thawte, etc.) but Comodo does not seem to even understand what they are and I&apos;m haing trouble getting a Comodo root kit that is compatible with the new Paypal system.

item.title: By: ben
item.dc:creator: ben
item.description:
in response to BradB.
Paypal just updated their root SSL certificates a few days ago, and it screwed a lot of folks up. Ryan&apos;s tag still works fine, its just that your host may need to update their root certs and add them to the java keystore in cfmx7. I had the same issue. it worked fine for years then it failed.
basically, until you update the certs on your machine with at least G2 certs from verisign, paypal won&apos;t answer a http request from coldfusion.
hope that helps
item.content:encoded:
in response to BradB.

I had the same issue. it worked fine for years then it failed.

basically, until you update the certs on your machine with at least G2 certs from verisign, paypal won't answer a http request from coldfusion.
